A sample of an ideal gas is enclosed in a cylinder with a piston that is free to move with negligible friction. The piston, which is initially at rest, has mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The air outside the cylinder is at pressure <math alttext="P sub atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>atm</mtext></msub></math>. (a) On the dot in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, which represents the piston, draw and label the forces (not components) that are exerted on the piston while the piston is at rest. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot. The lengths of the vectors should represent the relative magnitude of the forces.

(b) In Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, an external heat source slowly increases the temperature of the gas, causing the piston to move a distance <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> and then come to rest. Derive an expression for the work done by the gas on the piston during Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> as the piston moves a distance <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>. Express your answers in terms of <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math>, <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>, <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math>, <math alttext="P sub atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mtext>atm</mtext></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(c) In Process <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, which occurs after Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, the gas continues to be heated, but the piston is now held in place by pins, as shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math>, do the following.Sketch and label a curve or line starting on the dot (which represents the initial state of the gas) to represent Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.Sketch and label a curve or line to represent Process <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

(d) Indicate whether the graph of Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> in part (c) is consistent with the derivation for the work done by the gas on the piston during Process <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> from part (b). Briefly justify your answer by referencing both your derivation from part (b) and the graph in part (c).
